October 29, 1995: Fiction
THE LOST WORLD, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $25.95.) Scientists visit a Costa
Rican jungle that is the breeding ground of dinosaurs; a sequel to "Jurassic Park."
SILENT NIGHT, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $16.) A family finds
adversity and renewed courage during a Christmastime visit to New York.
THE HORSE WHISPERER, by Nicholas Evans. (Delacorte, $23.95.) A troubled
woman seeks solace for herself, her daughter and their horse from a wrangler in
Montana.
MORNING, NOON, AND NIGHT, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $24.) The
mysterious drowning of a respected tycoon leads to the revelation of a tangle of
scandals.
COMING HOME, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $25.95.) A British
woman comes of age during World War II.
COME TO GRIEF, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $23.95.) Sid Halley, champion
jockey turned investigator, probes the suicide of a revered racing figure's mother.
LOVE IN ANOTHER TOWN, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (HarperCollins, $15.) A
middle-aged woman, deserted by her husband, finds a new career and romance.
THE CELESTINE PROPHECY, by James Redfield. (Warner, $17.95.) An ancient
manuscript, found in Peru, provides insights into achieving a fulfilling life.
DEAD MAN'S WALK, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) The
adventures of two young Texas Rangers; a prequel to "Lonesome Dove."
BEACH MUSIC, by Pat Conroy. (Talese/Doubleday, $27.50.) An American living
in Rome returns to South Carolina and tries to cope with his past.
A PLACE CALLED FREEDOM, by Ken Follett. (Crown, $25.) Two Scots, fleeing
the injustices of their native land, find romance and freedom in 18th-century
America.
DARKSABER, by Kevin J. Anderson. (Spectra/Bantam, $22.95.) Luke Skywalker
and Han Solo of "Star Wars" encounter new challenges on returning to a desert
planet.
"L" IS FOR LAWLESS, by Sue Grafton. (Holt, $24.) Kinsey Millhone on the trail of
the cash and the culprits involved in a bank heist perpetrated decades ago.
FINDING MOON, by Tony Hillerman. (HarperCollins, $24.) A man's search for a
relative provides him with many escapades in war-torn Southeast Asia in the
October 29, 1995
Non-Fiction
MY AMERICAN JOURNEY, by Colin L. Powell with Joseph E. Persico. (Random
House, $25.95.) The autobiography of the former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of
Staff.
EMOTIONAL INTELLIGENCE, by Daniel Goleman. (Bantam, $23.95.) Factors
other than I.Q. that contribute to a successful and happy life.
A GOOD LIFE, by Ben Bradlee. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) The memoirs of the
former executive editor of The Washington Post.
MY POINT ... AND I DO HAVE ONE, by Ellen DeGeneres. (Bantam, $19.95.)
Observations on life and the pursuit of happiness by the television star and stand-
up comedian.
SPONTANEOUS HEALING, by Andrew Weil. (Knopf, $23.) A physician explains
the ways in which the body heals itself.
A GOOD WALK SPOILED, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $23.95.) A
sportswriter reports on the P.G.A. Tour in 1993 and 1994.
AN UNQUIET MIND, by Kay Redfield Jamison. (Knopf, $22.) A professor of
psychiatry recalls her struggle with manic depression.
MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random
House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga.
HIGH TIDE IN TUCSON, by Barbara Kingsolver. (HarperCollins, $22.) Essays
about motherhood, travel, natural history and other topics by the novelist.
SISTERS. Essays by Carol Saline. Photographs by Sharon J. Wohlmuth.
(Running Press, $27.50.) The relationships of 36 sets of sisters of varied callings
and backgrounds.
ALL I KNOW ABOUT ANIMAL BEHAVIOR I LEARNED IN LOEHMANN'S
DRESSING ROOM, by Erma Bombeck. (HarperCollins, $22.) Observations on the
strange ways of life in the 1990's.
PALIMPSEST, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $27.50.) The novelist and essayist
recalls his first 39 years (1925-64).
MY OLD MAN AND THE SEA, by David Hays and Daniel Hays. (Algonquin,
$19.95.) A sailing yarn about a father-and-son voyage from Connecticut around
Cape Horn.
COMING OF AGE, by Studs Terkel. (New Press, $25.) Some 70 men and women,
70 and older, look back on their lives and times.
